Posts.Content: rosasmommy wrote: Just curious whether others have had the unfortunate experience of having people to whom they were close suddenly disappear after your diagnosis.  My sister was extremely involved in my first diagnosis in 2008; I don't know how I would have gotten through treatment without her.  She started to distance herself from me and my family towards the end of treatment, however, to the point that we have not even spoken since March 2010.  We still don't know why as she refused to discuss what she calls the "past."  Fast forward to April 2011, we were slowly starting to reconnect, and then I got rediagnosied with Stage IV.  Since then, she has disappeared again without any explanation.  I have a great support network, so I can't complain about lack of support.  But it still hurts to have you own sister ignore how devestating a Stage IV diagnosis is.  Any one else deal with something similar?  Any thoughts?  Thanks in advance.  Natasha  Dx 4/8/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/8 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: rosasmommy wrote: I had a latismus flap reconstruction in 2009.  Recently I have been experiencing a lot of muscular pain in the donor site, as well as in the breast.  Just got back from my plastic surgeon, who told me I have a severe case of capsular contracture.  He gave me three options:  (1) do nothing; (2) take the implant out without putting in a replacement (i.e., I would not have a breast); and (3) remove all the damaged skin and replace it with skin from my abdomen (he stressed that the goal here would be replacement not reconstruction).  He said replacing the impant was not an option.  I'm curious why not -- my guess is that the fact that I have skin mets might have something to do with it.  Obviously I will follow up with him, but any thoughts from you all?  Anyone experience something similar?  Dx 4/8/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/8 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 06:53PM rosasmommy wrote: I had ovarian suppression + tamoxifen after my first diagnosis at age 32.  When I was diagnosed with mets (at age 35), I had an ooph after my first-line treatment (Taxol + Avastin) failed.  I wanted to do the ooph because I wanted to be absolutely sure that my ovaries were suppressed while I was taking Femara, especially because I'm young.  I also liked the fact that I could eliminate the Lupron shots.  The ooph wasn't that bad -- reocvery pretty easy.  Good luck with your decision!

Posts.Content: rosasmommy wrote: Hi everyone, I had a latismus flap reconstruction in 2009.  Recently I have been experiencing a lot of muscular pain in the donor site, as well as in the breast.  Just got back from my plastic surgeon, who told me I have a severe case of capsular contraction.  He gave me three options:  (1) do nothing; (2) take the implant out without putting in a replacement (i.e., I would not have a breast); and (3) remove all the damaged skin and replace it with skin from my abdomen (he stressed that the goal here would be replacement not reconstruction).  Option 1 leaves me with continued pain; option 2 leaves me without a breast; and option 3 gives me a mini-breast, but is major surgery.  Don't really like any of the options.  Feeling very overwhelmed.  What would you do? Posts.Content: rosasmommy wrote: I recently have had progression on Femara, so my oncologist is going to switch me to chemo.  Before determining my new treatment regiment, he ordered a biopsy to make sure my stats have remained the same.  Yay for being proactive......except he referred to an absolute idiot.  I have new skin lesions, so he sent me to a dermatologist to do a quick skin biopsy.  Some examples: - I don't know if I should take one or two samples -- what do you think? - So, we're going to biopsy the left breast?  Me:  No, the right breast, pointing to the exact spot.  Her (after calling my oncologist and confirming I was correct):  Oh, I took notes on a "scrap" of paper on Friday when your oncologist called me, and "they" threw out my paper scraps.  That was the issue. - Your oncologist wants to send the biopsy here.  I was thinking of sending it somewhere else.  What do you think?  Me:  I defer to my oncologist.  Her:  Oh...well I don't know how to send it to the place your oncologist wants me to send it to (a local hospital up the street from her), I wonder if they come and pick it up by courier? This conversation was repeated at least 4 to 5 times. -- my personal favorite:   "Why have you had so many biopsies in your right breast?  Wasn't the left breast the breast with the original cancer?" Seriously.....could she have inspired any less confidence???  Dx 4/8/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/8 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: rosasmommy wrote: Hi guys, Last week, I had a bone scan, which showed "new focal tracer uptake" in T1 and "new focal tracer activity in T8."  My oncologist ordered a follow-up MRI.  MRI results show "abnormal marrow signal" in the anterior segments of multiple vertebrae (all the thoracic vertebrae, except T8), and "marrow involvement involving the posterior elements of T5, T1, and T7.  The report says they are "non-expansive, they are not associated with soft tissue mass formation."  Reports states that  "diffuse metastatic disease would be favored." So....does that mean that I don't have any bone mets?  And I "just" have bone marrow mets?  Any significant difference between the two?  Do I need a biopsy to confirm the bone marrow mets (i.e., could my recent chemo, zometa, femara treatments somehow be the cause of the results)?  I am going to talk to my oncologist tomorrow.  Any thoughts on questions to ask would be greatly appreciated.  I'm totally stressed and confused at the moment.  Good news is that the MRI showed that my lung mass is the smallest it has been since my diagnosis.  Thanks in advance! Dx 4/8/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/8 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 01:45PM - edited Mar 2, 2012 01:46PM by rosasmommy I'm confused why this is posted in the Stage IV forum.  As others have noted, one of the hardest things about this diagnosis is knowing that we will ultimately be leaving our children without a mother.  As a mother of a 5 year old, it breaks my heart to think that I will not be around to watch her grow up into the amazing woman I know she will become.  And as a woman who was only 35 when diagnosed with Stage IV cancer, I struggle daily knowing that I will never have the second child I always hoped I would have.  I too froze embryos when I was initially diagnosed in 2008, and was just thinking about using them when I had my Stage IV recurrence.  So no, I don't have any advice on using and/or finding a surrogate.  I wish I did.   Setting that all aside, I think you and your friends need to think about this plan.  Seems somewhat naive, to put it mildly.

Posts.Content: rosasmommy wrote: As some of you may remember, my sister took a unexplained "break" from our family in January 2010.  She virtually disappeared, and continued to be absent, even after I informed her that I had been diagnosed with mets in April 2011.  Six months after my mets diagnosis, she tried to reestablish communication with me, but has refused to provide any explanation for her absence.  Recently, she sent me an e-mail asking me to give her an idea of my "day-to-day" life.  So, I sent her a detailed e-mail in which I expressed my fear of dying, my fear of leaving my daughter without a mother, and how mentally and physically battered I feel.  Her response:  thank you for providing this information so I can make the prayers I say for you each day more specific.  WTF!  In response to my statements that I feel abandoned by her, she told me that I need to let go of my anger so that we can enjoy the time we have left.  Again, WTF!  I just don't understand how she can abandon me at a time I need her most.  So, so hurtful.  :( Dx 4/8/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/8 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 07:56AM rosasmommy wrote: You are an amazing friend!  The fact that you've come here to find out ways to best support your friend shows that you probably are already doing what you need to support her.  She is lucky to have you!!  I am in a similar position to your friend -- 32 at first diagnosis, 35 at Stage IV diagnosis, with a 5 year old daughter.  The biggest thing for me is having people help me support my daughter and try to keep her life as normal as possible.  I have really appreciated people who have volunteered to take her to swim lessons, have her over for a play date, bring her to school functions, etc.  Especially during those first days, your friend is going need space to process her feelings, so the more you can take the kids out of the house, the better.  The other thing is being there for her, and allowing her to feel comfortable expressing her feelings (good and bad).  I really value people who allow me to say what I want to say as opposed to making me feel like I need to protect them from my cancer!  Finally, as others have noted, keep doing the things you used to do together (movies, pedicures, etc.).  It will help her feel as "normal" as possible.  Feel free to PM with any questions.  Or if your friend wants to talk to someone in a similar position, I am just a PM away.   P.S.  I almost forgot to say FOOD!  Going through treatment is exhausting, especially if she is trying to work through treatment.  Coming home and not having to worry about dinner is a huge help!!!  P.S.S.  To the extent she has a huge circle of family and friends she would like to keep updated about her treatment, you could offer to be the point person for that.  Two of my closest friends took the lead organizing all the people who offered to help with food, childcare, etc. and providing my family and friends with regular updates.  I really appreciated it!

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2011 02:31PM rosasmommy wrote: Hi Oklandmama, First off, I am so sorry you are going through this.  Life can be so cruel.  I am 36 years, with a 5 year old daughter.  Parenting with mets is definitely a challenge, but it can be done.  Do you have family/friends who can help take care of your kids?  Particularly during the first days of my mets diagnosis, I needed time to grieve the loss of life as I wanted it to be, process my diagnosis, and gather my strength so I could be there for my daughter.   It really helped to drop her off at a friend's house for a playdate, just so I could have space.  Also ask your family/friendsto bring meals.  Anything that can be taken off your plate helps.  As to the emotional blow of a Stage IV diagnosis, I asked my oncologist for an antidepressant/anti-anxiety.  Definitely helps keep my head in a good place.  No doubt about it though -- some days are easier than others. That being said, you need to give yourself some time to process this.  Life will slowly adjust to the "new normal," but allow yourself some time, as I put it, "grieve for the life I almost had."  Feel to PM with any questions or just to talk.  Sending lots of love your way.  You are not alone -- we are all here to support you.  Post this on the Stage IV board, and I'm sure you'll get a lot more responses.  Natasha

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 07:55PM - edited Dec 30, 2011 07:57PM by rosasmommy I've been doing Taxol and Avastin since April 2011. I don't have any experience with Herceptin, but based on my experiences with Taxol, the main SEs are hair loss, fatigue, and neuropathy.  I haven't had a real problem with nausea, as long as I eat little meals thoughout the day to keep something in my stomach (similar to what I did during pregnancy to fight morning sicknes).  I would shave her head when her hair starts to fall off (mine started to go after my second round).  She'll know it's starting to fall off because the hair follicles will start to hurt.  As to the fatigue, my oncologist always says that exercise helps with the fatigue -- a lot easier said than done, I know!!  That being said, on the days I am really fatigued, I do try to take a little walk around the block, and I find it perks me up a bit.  As to the neuropathy, you can get amino acids from Whole Foods or heath food store to take -- I can't remember the names or the dosages, but I'm sure the oncologist or the oncologist nurse can help.  I also second keeping an eye on the digestive track, as constipation can become a problem. I take a colace for the first few days after an infusion, and it does the trick. And don't be afaid to ask for anti-anxiety/anti-depressants to help during the first days of the diagnosis.  I take both, and don't know what I would do without them.  They really help keep the really dark thoughts in check. Good luck!  You sound like an amazing husband.  Remember to take time to take care of you too!  Take advantage of all the offers to help.  If anyone asks what they can do, tell them to bring food!  It is so nice to come from chemo and not have to worry about making dinner.  Having a friend coordinate the meal delivery service is also helpful.  Websites like 'lotsahelpinghands" can help with that too.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2012 09:05PM rosasmommy wrote: dbla -- be careful before you use a recording device.  Depending on what state you're in, it can be illegal to record a person without their consent.  And companies often have policies prohibiting recording work-related conversations.  Don't want to give them a reason to discipline you!  I agree what others have said -- consult your union rep.  Cancer is a disability that is covered under the ADA so you have the right to request that your employer accomodate you.  The fact that you have a good performance history is in your favor.  Makes it seem much more sucipicious if they suddenly start to find performance issues.  One last word of advice -- document everything.  You want to make sure that you have a good record to the extent things start to go south.  Good luck!!
